qas.question: Who wrote Max Clifford: Read All About It?
Who was writing a book with McCaffrey?
Who was previously Starr's public relations agent?
How did attention from the story impact Starr's career?

answers.text: the attention helped to revive his career

qas.question: What was the name of Starr's autobiography?

context: According to Max Clifford: Read All About It, written by <a0_0>Clifford and Angela Levin<a0_0/>, La Salle invented the story out of frustration with <a1_0>Starr<a1_0/> who had been working on a book with McCaffrey. She contacted an acquaintance who worked for The Sun in Manchester. The story reportedly delighted MacKenzie, who was keen to run it, and <a2_0>Max Clifford<a2_0/>, who had been Starr's public relations agent. Starr had to be persuaded that the apparent revelation would not damage him; <a3_0>the attention helped to revive his career<a3_0/>. In his 2001 autobiography <a4_0>Unwrapped<a4_0/>, Starr wrote that the incident was a complete fabrication: "I have never eaten or even nibbled a live hamster, gerbil, guinea pig, mouse, shrew, vole or any other small mammal."
